asia.name: Bengal Tiger
asia.short: The iconic tiger of Asia with a striking orange coat and black stripes.
asia.more: Bengal tigers are the most numerous tiger subspecies, primarily found in India and Bangladesh. They play a vital role as apex predators in maintaining ecological balance in forests. Despite conservation efforts, their populations remain threatened due to habitat loss, poaching, and human–wildlife conflict.
details: Habitat: Tropical forests, mangroves, and grasslands
Diet: Carnivorous, mainly deer, wild boar, and buffalo
Conservation Status: Endangered
Average Lifespan: 8–10 years in the wild

asia.name: Giant Panda
asia.short: A beloved bear species from China known for its black-and-white fur.
asia.more: Giant pandas are symbols of wildlife conservation worldwide. They are unique among bears for their bamboo-based diet, and their specialized teeth and strong jaws reflect this adaptation. Intensive conservation programs and habitat restoration have helped improve their status, though they remain vulnerable.
details: Habitat: Temperate bamboo forests in Sichuan, Shaanxi, and Gansu provinces
Diet: 99% bamboo, occasionally small animals or eggs
Conservation Status: Vulnerable
Average Lifespan: 20 years in the wild, up to 30 in captivity

asia.name: Orangutan
asia.short: Intelligent, tree-dwelling primates from Borneo and Sumatra.
asia.more: Orangutans are among the closest relatives to humans and known for their remarkable problem-solving abilities and use of tools. They spend most of their lives in trees and play an essential ecological role as seed dispersers. Their populations are declining rapidly due to deforestation and illegal wildlife trade.
details: Habitat: Tropical rainforests of Borneo and Sumatra
Diet: Fruits, leaves, bark, insects, and occasionally small vertebrates
Conservation Status: Critically Endangered
Average Lifespan: 30–40 years in the wild

asia.name: Asian Elephant
asia.short: A gentle giant native to forests and grasslands across Asia.
asia.more: Asian elephants are highly intelligent animals with strong social structures and impressive memory. They help maintain forest ecosystems by dispersing seeds and creating pathways. Sadly, they face threats from habitat fragmentation, poaching, and collisions with human settlements.
details: Habitat: Grasslands, forests, and scrublands across India, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia
Diet: Herbivorous, consuming grasses, fruits, and bark
Conservation Status: Endangered
Average Lifespan: 60 years in the wild

asia.name: Snow Leopard
asia.short: An elusive mountain cat adapted to cold, rocky terrain.
asia.more: Snow leopards are rarely seen due to their stealth and remote habitats. Their thick fur and powerful limbs allow them to navigate steep mountain slopes with ease. Their populations are threatened by poaching, climate change, and loss of prey species.
details: Habitat: High-altitude mountains (3,000–4,500 m) across Central Asia
Diet: Wild sheep, goats, and smaller mammals
Conservation Status: Vulnerable
Average Lifespan: 10–12 years in the wild

asia.name: Red Panda
asia.short: A small, tree-loving mammal with reddish fur and a ringed tail.
asia.more: Red pandas are solitary and primarily nocturnal animals known for their agility in navigating forest canopies. Although they share a name with giant pandas, they belong to a distinct taxonomic family. Their survival is threatened by deforestation, climate change, and fragmented habitats.
details: Habitat: Temperate forests with dense bamboo understories
Diet: Bamboo, fruits, berries, insects, and small mammals
Conservation Status: Endangered
Average Lifespan: 8–10 years in the wild

north_america.name: American Bison
north_america.short: The massive bison roaming the plains of North America.
north_america.more: American bison are iconic symbols of the Great Plains. Once near extinction due to overhunting, they have been reintroduced to protected areas. They play a crucial role in shaping grassland ecosystems.
details: Habitat: Grasslands and prairies
Diet: Herbivorous, mainly grasses
Conservation Status: Near Threatened
Average Lifespan: 15–20 years in the wild

north_america.name: Grey Wolf
north_america.short: The apex predator of North American forests and tundra.
north_america.more: Grey wolves live in packs with complex social structures. They control prey populations and maintain ecosystem balance. Wolves were historically hunted but now benefit from conservation programs.
details: Habitat: Forests, tundras, and mountains
Diet: Carnivorous, mainly deer, elk, and small mammals
Conservation Status: Least Concern
Average Lifespan: 6–8 years in the wild

north_america.name: Bald Eagle
north_america.short: The majestic bird of prey and symbol of the United States.
north_america.more: Bald eagles are powerful hunters that feed mainly on fish. Their populations have rebounded due to bans on pesticides and protection programs, symbolizing successful conservation efforts.
details: Habitat: Near lakes, rivers, and coastal regions
Diet: Fish, small mammals, and carrion
Conservation Status: Least Concern
Average Lifespan: 20–30 years in the wild

north_america.name: Moose
north_america.short: The largest deer species with imposing antlers.
north_america.more: Moose are solitary herbivores adapted to cold climates. They feed on aquatic plants and shrubs, playing a role in maintaining vegetation balance in their habitats.
details: Habitat: Boreal forests and wetlands
Diet: Herbivorous, leaves, twigs, and aquatic plants
Conservation Status: Least Concern
Average Lifespan: 15–20 years in the wild

north_america.name: Raccoon
north_america.short: A clever, nocturnal mammal known for its masked face.
north_america.more: Raccoons are highly adaptable omnivores that thrive near human settlements. They are known for their dexterity and intelligence, often raiding trash and food sources.
details: Habitat: Forests, urban areas, and wetlands
Diet: Omnivorous, fruits, insects, small animals, and human food
Conservation Status: Least Concern
Average Lifespan: 2–3 years in the wild, up to 20 in captivity

north_america.name: Grizzly Bear
north_america.short: A large, powerful bear inhabiting forests and mountains.
north_america.more: Grizzly bears are apex predators and key ecosystem engineers. They dig for roots, disperse seeds, and prey on ungulates. Human conflict and habitat loss remain major threats.
details: Habitat: Forests, mountains, and tundra
Diet: Omnivorous, fish, berries, small mammals, and carrion
Conservation Status: Least Concern
Average Lifespan: 20–25 years in the wild

africa.name: African Lion
africa.short: The king of the savanna, known for its strength and pride structure.
africa.more: African lions are social cats living in prides. They are apex predators that control herbivore populations, ensuring healthy ecosystems. Threats include habitat loss and human conflict.
details: Habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and open woodlands
Diet: Carnivorous, mainly zebras, antelopes, and buffalo
Conservation Status: Vulnerable
Average Lifespan: 10–14 years in the wild

africa.name: African Elephant
africa.short: The largest land animal, known for its intelligence and strong social bonds.
africa.more: African elephants shape landscapes by uprooting trees and creating water holes. They live in matriarchal herds and face threats from poaching and habitat fragmentation.
details: Habitat: Savannas, forests, and deserts
Diet: Herbivorous, grasses, fruits, and bark
Conservation Status: Endangered
Average Lifespan: 60–70 years in the wild

africa.name: Cheetah
africa.short: The fastest land animal, built for sprinting across the savanna.
africa.more: Cheetahs hunt primarily during the day using speed and stealth. They are solitary or live in small groups. Habitat loss and declining prey numbers threaten their populations.
details: Habitat: Grasslands and open plains
Diet: Carnivorous, mainly antelopes and small mammals
Conservation Status: Vulnerable
Average Lifespan: 10–12 years in the wild

africa.name: Hippopotamus
africa.short: A massive semi-aquatic mammal spending much of its time in rivers.
africa.more: Hippos are key ecosystem engineers in rivers, shaping channels and distributing nutrients. They are aggressive and territorial but crucial for aquatic biodiversity.
details: Habitat: Rivers, lakes, and wetlands
Diet: Herbivorous, mainly grasses
Conservation Status: Vulnerable
Average Lifespan: 40–50 years in the wild

africa.name: Giraffe
africa.short: The tallest land animal, easily recognized by its long neck.
africa.more: Giraffes feed on leaves from tall trees and play an important role in controlling vegetation. Social structures are loose, and they face threats from poaching and habitat fragmentation.
details: Habitat: Savannas and open woodlands
Diet: Herbivorous, leaves and shoots
Conservation Status: Vulnerable
Average Lifespan: 25 years in the wild

africa.name: Zebra
africa.short: A striking black-and-white striped herbivore of African plains.
africa.more: Zebras live in social herds and are prey for lions and hyenas. Their grazing helps maintain grassland ecosystems. Populations face threats from hunting and habitat loss.
details: Habitat: Grasslands and savannas
Diet: Herbivorous, grasses and shoots
Conservation Status: Least Concern
Average Lifespan: 20–25 years in the wild
